dataObjects.description: Described from streams around Myitkina and Indawgyi Lake in northern Myanmar. Another population was discovered in the Irrawaddy delta near Einme. A third locality was identified near Mandalay in 1996; the site was resurveyed in 2003 but the species was not found.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: Body color usually uniform or with weak reticulate pattern formed by dark scale margins, very rarely any vertical bars.  No caudal, cleithral or opercular blotches.  Lateral line scales usually 23, rarely 22 or 24; transverse scale row 8.5; vertebrae usually 25.  Palatine teeth absent.  Anguloarticular lateralis canal present.  Males with black blotch anteriorly in dorsal fin (Ref. 46238).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Conservation
dataObjects.title: IUCN Red List Assessment
dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.rightsHolder: International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Britz, R. 2010. Dario hysginon. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Red List Category
LC
Least Concern

Red List Criteria

Version
3.1

Year Assessed
2010

Assessor/s
Britz, R.

Reviewer/s
Jha, B.R., Datta, N.C., Chaudhry, S. & Allen, D.J.

Contributor/s
Molur, S.

Justification
Dario hysginon was described from streams around Myitkina and Indawgyi Lake in northern Myanmar. Another population was discovered in the Irrawaddy delta near Einme. A third locality was identified near Mandalay in 1996; the site was resurveyed in 2003 but the species was not found.

The three known locations represent a large area of the Irrawaddy system, but there is not information on the species distribution between these areas; the upper Irrawaddy has not been heavily surveyed and further populations may be present. Parts of the southern part of Myanmar has also not been heavily sampled. It is potentially easily overlooked.

Whilst the species does not have a large number of known localities, these are widespread through the Irrawaddy basin, and it is at least assessed as Least Concern. further work is clearly required, especially following the recent Cyclone Nargis which most likely impacted the southern Delta population. In addition, further taxonomic work is required to confirm that all three species are a single species.
